user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_send_iovec_:
```c
ssize_t
MHD_send_iovec_ (struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                 struct MHD_iovec_track_ *const r_iov,
                 bool push_data)
{
#ifdef MHD_VECT_SEND
#if defined(HTTPS_SUPPORT) || \
  defined(_MHD_VECT_SEND_NEEDS_SPIPE_SUPPRESSED)
  bool use_iov_send = true;
#endif /* HTTPS_SUPPORT || _MHD_VECT_SEND_NEEDS_SPIPE_SUPPRESSED */
#endif /* MHD_VECT_SEND */

  mhd_assert (NULL != connection->rp.resp_iov.iov);
  mhd_assert (NULL != connection->rp.response->data_iov);
  mhd_assert (connection->rp.resp_iov.cnt > connection->rp.resp_iov.sent);
#ifdef MHD_VECT_SEND
#if defined(HTTPS_SUPPORT) || \
  defined(_MHD_VECT_SEND_NEEDS_SPIPE_SUPPRESSED)
#ifdef HTTPS_SUPPORT
  use_iov_send = use_iov_send &&
                 (0 == (connection->daemon->options & MHD_USE_TLS));
#endif /* HTTPS_SUPPORT */
#ifdef _MHD_VECT_SEND_NEEDS_SPIPE_SUPPRESSED
  use_iov_send = use_iov_send && (connection->daemon->sigpipe_blocked ||
                                  connection->sk_spipe_suppress);
#endif /* _MHD_VECT_SEND_NEEDS_SPIPE_SUPPRESSED */
  if (use_iov_send)
#endif /* HTTPS_SUPPORT || _MHD_VECT_SEND_NEEDS_SPIPE_SUPPRESSED */
  return send_iov_nontls (connection, r_iov, push_data);
#endif /* MHD_VECT_SEND */

#if ! defined(MHD_VECT_SEND) || defined(HTTPS_SUPPORT) || \
  defined(_MHD_VECT_SEND_NEEDS_SPIPE_SUPPRESSED)
  return send_iov_emu (connection, r_iov, push_data);
#endif /* !MHD_VECT_SEND || HTTPS_SUPPORT
          || _MHD_VECT_SEND_NEEDS_SPIPE_SUPPRESSED */
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I inspected the entire provided function. There are no calls to memcmp (nor to strcmp/strncmp) and no comparisons of null-terminated strings in this fragment. The code only performs pointer null-checks, integer/bitmask comparisons (e.g. (0 == (connection->daemon->options & MHD_USE_TLS))), asserts, macro-controlled returns, and calls to send_iov_nontls/send_iov_emu. Those called functions are outside the provided fragment — if their implementations are to be checked for Rule 21.14, their source must be provided. Based on the supplied code alone, there are no memcmp usages to investigate for Rule 21.14.
